publicwhip.spmotion: *S1M-1926# Mr Duncan McNeil: Local Newspaper Week, 14 to 20 May 2001—That the Parliament welcomes Local Newspaper Week; recognises that local newspapers play a crucial role in their communities and can act as a focal point of community life; acknowledges that they provide valuable services such as scrutiny of local elected representatives and the championing of local causes; further acknowledges that they are a window on our communities and give us a unique opportunity to present all that is positive within our areas to a wider audience, and notes that the Greenock Telegraph is a fine example of these roles.

S1M-1926# Mr Duncan McNeil: Local Newspaper Week, 14 to 20 May 2001—That the Parliament welcomes Local Newspaper Week; recognises that local newspapers play a crucial role in their communities and can act as a focal point of community life; acknowledges that they provide valuable services such as scrutiny of local elected representatives and the championing of local causes; further acknowledges that they are a window on our communities and give us a unique opportunity to present all that is positive within our areas to a wider audience, and notes that the Greenock Telegraph is a fine example of these roles.
S1M-1926# Local Newspaper Week, 14 to 20 May 2001 (lodged on 10 May 2001) Tricia Marwick*
S1M-1926# Local Newspaper Week, 14 to 20 May 2001 (lodged on 10 May 2001) Linda Fabiani*, Mr Michael McMahon*, Donald Gorrie*, Mr Jamie Stone*, Irene Oldfather*
S1M-1926# Local Newspaper Week, 14 to 20 May 2001 (lodged on 10 May 2001) Pauline McNeill*, Scott Barrie*, Mr Jamie McGrigor*
S1M-1926# Local Newspaper Week, 14 to 20 May 2001 (lodged on 10 May 2001) Mrs Mary Mulligan*, Mike Watson*, Rhoda Grant*, Karen Whitefield*, Dr Elaine Murray*

S1M-1926# Mr Duncan McNeil: Local Newspaper Week, 14 to 20 May 2001—That the Parliament welcomes Local Newspaper Week; recognises that local newspapers play a crucial role in their communities and can act as a focal point of community life; acknowledges that they provide valuable services such as scrutiny of local elected representatives and the championing of local causes; further acknowledges that they are a window on our communities and give us a unique opportunity to present all that is positive within our areas to a wider audience, and notes that the Greenock Telegraph is a fine example of these roles. Supported by: Tricia Marwick, Linda Fabiani, Mr Michael McMahon, Donald Gorrie, Mr Jamie Stone, Irene Oldfather, Pauline McNeill, Scott Barrie, Mr Jamie McGrigor, Mrs Mary Mulligan, Mike Watson, Rhoda Grant, Karen Whitefield, Dr Elaine Murray
S1M-1926# Local Newspaper Week, 14 to 20 May 2001 (lodged on 10 May 2001) Fiona McLeod*
S1M-1926# Local Newspaper Week, 14 to 20 May 2001 (lodged on 10 May 2001) Mary Scanlon*, Paul Martin*
S1M-1926# Local Newspaper Week, 14 to 20 May 2001 (lodged on 10 May 2001) Alex Neil*, Mr John Home Robertson*, Des McNulty*, Cathy Peattie*
